article:
{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Department of the Air Force DAF
|seal = Seal of the US Air Force.svg |seal_width = 155px |seal_caption = Seal of
the U.S. Department of the Air Force |formed = September 18, 1947 |preceding1 =
Department of War |jurisdiction = |headquarters = |employees = 330,159 Regular
Air Force 151,360 Civilians 68,872 Air Force Reserve 94,753 Air
National Guard |budget = $170.6 billion (2010 Budget Request) |image =
|chief1_name = Michael B. Donley |parent_agency = U.S. Department of Defense
|child1_agency = |website = [http://www.af.mil www.af.mil] }} The 'Department of
the Air Force' ('DAF') is one of the three Military Departments within the
Department of Defense of the United States of America. The Department of the Air
Force was formed on September 18, 1947, per the National Security Act of 1947
and it includes all elements and units of the United States Air Force (USAF).

The Department of the Air Force is headed by the Secretary of the Air Force
(SAF/OS), a civilian, who has the authority to conduct all of its affairs,
subject to the authority, direction and control of the Secretary of Defense. The
Secretary of the Air Force's principal deputy is the Under Secretary of the Air
Force (SAF/US). Their senior staff assistants in the Office of the Secretary of
the Air Force are four Assistant Secretaries for Acquisition, Financial
Management & Comptroller, Installations, Environment & Logistics, Manpower &
Reserve Affairs and a General Counsel. The highest ranking military officer in
the department is the Chief of Staff of the Air Force who is the senior
uniformed adviser to the Secretary, represents the Air Force on the Joint Chiefs
of Staff, heads the Air Staff and is assisted in the latter capacity by the Vice
Chief of Staff of the Air Force.

By direction of the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of the Air Force assigns
Air Force units - apart from those units performing duties enumerated in unless
otherwise directed - to the Commanders of the Combatant Commands. Only the
Secretary of Defense (and the President) has the authority to approve transfer
of forces between Combatant Commands.
categories: Former United States Executive Departments|Air Force
